text: this is Michael's Lachman Berlin bureau
chief of the New York Times since
starting my assignment here six months
ago I find I am often confronted with
Germany's many contradictions but one of
the most glaring or perhaps perplexing
is its favorite street food the curry
Wurst
deep-fried pork sausage very German cut
into little chunks doused with three
squirts of ketchup quintessential
American and of course sprinkled with a
coating of curry powder compliments of
India by way of Britain currywurst is
often accompanied by a big pile of
french fries topped with the heaping
mound of mayonnaise it's a guilty
pleasure to be sure in health obsessed
City claim that curry Wurst is actually
a democratizing dish because bankers and
Boxster's construction workers and
businessmen enjoy it standing side by
side car reversed is a confection of the
post-world War 2 era the story goes that
in 1949 a Berlin vendor started serving
sausages using American ketchup
covered with curry powder it dominated
the street for decades but was almost
knocked off its throne as king of fast
food in the early 1970s Turkish
immigrants began selling the doner kebab
like the middle-eastern swarmer is
slivers of meat packed into a Peter or
rolled in a flatbread it's cheap tasty
and its filling
village-like today as Berlin becomes a
more international City fast food shops
of every variety are popping up from
soup kitchens to noodle houses and sushi
bars but there remains no food it seems
closer to the Berliners heart and that
unique melange of flavors spices and
greasy pork sausage known as the khari
burst
